GLOSSARY 
 
  foresight  –  a discipline related to futures studies that examines emerging 
threats and opportunities and uses scenarios to make sense 
of social change (ADB. 2020. Futures Thinking in Asia and 
the Pacific: Why Foresight Matters for Policy Makers. Manila.) 
  futures  –  the study of various and alternative images of the future and 
thinking  the worldviews and values that support them; the use of the 
plural futures is deliberate to focus on multiple futures. (ADB. 
2020. Futures Thinking in Asia and the Pacific: Why Foresight 
Matters for Policy Makers. Manila.) 
  knowledge  –  process of ensuring proper generation, storage, acquisition, 
management  dissemination,  and  use  of  knowledge  to  meet  an 
organization’s objectives 
  knowledge  –  knowledge-based  practical  ideas,  designs,  approaches, 
solution  products,  and  processes  that  resolve  problems  (ADB 
[Department of Communications; Economic Research and 
Regional Cooperation Department; Sustainable Development 
and Climate Change Department; and Strategy, Policy and 
Partnerships Department]. 2019. Measuring, Reporting and 
Recognizing  Knowledge  Products  and  Services  and 
Knowledge Solutions. Memorandum. 19 October [internal]) 
  silo  –  organizational entities that lack the desire or motivation to 
coordinate (at worst, even communicate) with other entities in 
the  same  organization.  (O.  Serrat.  2010.  Bridging 
Organizational Silos. Manila.) 
  systems  –  a holistic approach to analysis that focuses on the way a 
thinking  system's constituent parts interrelate and how systems work 
over time and within the context of larger systems: it is the 
opposite of thinking in silos (ADB. 2020. Futures Thinking in 
Asia  and  the  Pacific:  Why  Foresight  Matters  for  Policy 
Makers. Manila.)

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  strengthen  knowledge 
management and innovation in the operations of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to deliver 
tailored knowledge and innovative solutions for its developing member countries (DMCs).1 It will 
enhance DMCs’ capacity to address complex development challenges. The TA will support ADB 
in implementing its Knowledge Management Action Plan (KMAP) 2021–2025, which aims to 
improve the impact, quality, and efficiency of ADB’s knowledge using a country-differentiated 
approach.2 
 
2.  The TA was endorsed in the corporate priority framework meeting in November 2020 and 
is  included  in  the  2021  Management-approved  results-based  workplan  of  the  Sustainable 
Development and Climate Change Department. It operationalizes ADB’s Strategy 2030 agenda 
to  strengthen  ADB  as a  knowledge  and  integrated  solutions  provider,3 and  aligns  with  all 
operational priorities, particularly accelerating progress in gender equality and strengthening 
governance and institutional capacity.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  ADB has provided knowledge and financial support since 1967 amid a rapidly evolving 
development landscape, enabling it to stay relevant as a trusted knowledge solutions provider in 
the region. Under Strategy 2030, ADB has renewed its commitment to work closely with DMCs to 
identify their needs and produce relevant and customized knowledge solutions. The KMAP gives 
effect to this commitment. Knowledge management is critical to building an understanding of the 
current and future needs of DMCs and identifying the operational areas where ADB can add the 
most value, building on both past experience and present and emerging expertise. In policy 
dialogues, it facilitates efficient access to knowledge and better use of informed planning and 
decision-making processes.  
 
4.  The KMAP’s overarching objective is for ADB to better deliver tailored knowledge solutions 
alongside financing. It will strengthen the country knowledge plan (CKP) process, which outlines 
ADB’s knowledge support to its DMCs. The CKP holds the potential for customizing knowledge 
solutions to respond to DMCs’ specific current and future development needs. However, the 2021 
country partnership strategy (CPS) review indicated that the previous CKP and list of indicative 
knowledge products and events added limited value. There is a need to improve the value addition 
of CKPs to (i) support project pipelines or (ii) align with the respective CPS while also serving as 
a forward-looking document that anticipates a DMC’s emerging needs.5 Moreover, the 2020 
evaluation of ADB’s knowledge solutions for development found gaps in the process by which 
ADB  identifies  regional  and  country  knowledge  needs,  and  highlighted  the  importance  of 
conducting extensive consultations with the government and other stakeholders, and having an 
integrated and rapid approach for providing knowledge solutions.6 It underscores the need for a 
more strategic and enhanced CKP process.

5.  Underpinning the need for a better approach to CKPs and programming is the fact that 
DMCs increasingly struggle with complex challenges that cannot be addressed with traditional 
projects and engagement avenues. The current unprecedented volatility—evidenced, for example, 
by the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) crisis—is encouraging DMCs to look to innovation to 
tackle COVID-19’s severe impacts and the urgent need for rapid recovery while addressing 
underlying  systemic  weaknesses.  The  need  for  more  resilient  development  solutions  is 
increasingly clear. DMCs require agile and integrated responses, financing, and knowledge 
across sectors and themes to recover from the economic and social shocks caused by COVID-
19. Only a few DMCs (India, Nepal, People’s Republic of China, and Viet Nam) were ranked as 
innovative in the Global Innovation Index for 2020,7 with the scores of many others lagging or 
falling. ADB needs to support innovation that will help it build, invest in, and leverage an 
ecosystem of stakeholders and experts to help DMCs become knowledge economies and expand 
innovation. 8 Increased knowledge and innovation capacity will equip DMCs and ADB to navigate 
sustainable development in a complex and volatile environment. 
 
6.  ADB value addition. Building on the KMAP actions, the TA will use the One ADB 
approach to address the need of DMCs for tailored knowledge and innovation. It will apply the 
enhanced CKP process of ADB’s Strategy, Policy and Partnerships Department formulated with 
the Knowledge Advisory Services Center of the Sustainable Development and Climate Change 
Department (SDCC-KC) to develop a more structured and integrated response to enhancing 
DMCs’ capacity to absorb and apply knowledge. The TA will foster partnerships and regional 
cooperation. It will also improve the knowledge management capacity (KMC) of DMC government 
officials (a significant proportion of whom will be women) to address development issues across 
agencies and implement policy reforms. ADB’s principle of applying a differentiated approach is 
critical to address the varying needs and institutional knowledge management and innovation 
capacities of DMCs. 
 
7.  Lessons from previous and ongoing ADB projects. In 2019, ADB developed an 
enhanced CKP approach that involves a rigorous process for assessing country knowledge needs 
and prioritizing ADB’s response.9 This TA will support and scale up this process across more 
DMCs by developing more knowledge products to help teams develop CKPs independently. 
Significant progress has been made in mainstreaming innovative thinking and introducing new 
modalities for identifying, designing, and delivering projects. In 2015, ADB approved TA to 
strengthen the capacity of DMCs to solve development problems using innovative solutions.10 In 
2018, ADB (i) launched the technology innovation challenge to build DMC capacity to address 
specific development challenges through partnerships with technology providers;11  and (ii) 
piloted its first Futures Thinking and Foresight program, and engaged with seven DMCs to explore 
how ADB can engage on a more future-oriented policy dialogue.12 Lessons drawn by this TA 
include the need to (i) ensure a balance between supply- and demand-driven knowledge using 
futures thinking and foresight; (ii) break silos through more collaborative relationships among 
various stakeholders using systems thinking; (iii) ground innovation in specific problems and

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: DMCs’ socioeconomic development (including 
recovery from global pandemics such as COVID-19) is informed by ADB’s knowledge-based and 
country-focused policies, programs, and operational experience.13 The TA will have the following 
outcome: Use of knowledge management and innovative development planning tools by DMCs 
increased.14 The outputs will be (i) integrated approach for strengthening country knowledge 
programming  delivered,  (ii)  regional  and  country-level  innovation  supported,  and  (iii)  DMC 
capacity in knowledge management and innovation improved. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output 1: Integrated approach for strengthening country knowledge programming 
delivered. The TA will (i) (a) support operations departments and resident missions to develop 
ADB  departmental  knowledge  management  roadmaps  to  clarify  measures  in  designing 
knowledge that fits local conditions, and (b) where needed, knowledge management specialists 
will be fielded in resident missions to strengthen their KMC; and (ii) institutionalize and scale up 
the enhanced CKP process to DMCs with planned or ongoing CPSs to provide them with 
responsive knowledge solutions. As needed and in collaboration with resident missions, the TA 
will extend institutional knowledge management support for DMCs as being done by ADB for the 
Philippines’  National  Economic  Development  Authority.15 Best  practices  in  developing  an 
enhanced CKP, guides, and manuals will be featured on a CKP portal that is under development 
through ongoing TA (footnote 9). Partnerships with development partners, universities, think tanks, 
and regional organizations will be explored to enhance strategic knowledge support for DMCs.16 
Results will be captured and disseminated through blogs, infographics, and videos. 
 
10.  Output 2: Regional and country-level innovation supported. This output will enable 
ADB, DMCs, and knowledge and innovation partners to design innovative solutions to address 
DMCs’ knowledge needs. The output will (i) support the establishment of an ADB knowledge and 
innovation hub, drawing from existing hubs,17 experiences from collaboration with innovative 
partners through new communities and platforms such as Tech For Impact,18 insights drawn from

11.  Output 3: Developing member country capacity in knowledge management and 
innovation improved. This output will complement Outputs 1 and 2 to ensure sustainability of 
ADB knowledge support to DMCs. The output will design and deliver (i) training programs such 
as fundamentals of knowledge management, human-centered design thinking, futures thinking 
and foresight; (ii) eLearning courses; and (iii) learning events such as Innovation Fair, Knowledge 
Forum, and TEDx-style public speaking knowledge solution roundtables in DMCs. Focus will be 
given to the leadership capacity of women to implement knowledge management and innovation 
to  reinforce  their  active  role  in  policy  design  and  setting  priorities  that  have  significant 
development impacts. The output will provide flexibility to respond to the needs of DMCs and 
regional organizations to build KMC (footnote 16).  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund ($500,000 under TASF 7 and $500,000 under TASF-other 
sources). The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  ADB, through SDCC-KC, will administer the TA and will be the executing agency. SDCC-
KC will implement the TA in close coordination with ADB operations departments and resident 
missions. While all DMCs will benefit from the TA, targeted support will be extended to resident 
missions that have requested support. Institutional knowledge management and innovation 
support for DMCs will be identified and coordinated with respective resident missions. Reporting 
mechanisms such as monitoring briefs, after-action reviews, and guides will be developed to 
facilitate TA implementation.

this action to the Board.
